1119262724951805954.text: Our traditions may differ but we all share one world and one moon. Thinking of many colleagues and friends celebrating Passover, Easter, and Mid-Sha'ban this weekend. These three holidays are all linked to the phases of the moon.https://twitter.com/NASAMoon/status/1118948756060352512 …

1116429736601899009.text: While @NASA regrets the end of the @TeamSpaceIL mission without a successful lunar landing, we congratulate SpaceIL, Israel Aerospace Industries and the state of Israel on the accomplishment of sending the first privately funded mission into lunar orbit. https://go.nasa.gov/2Ir4I7L pic.twitter.com/cfMtP4srDr

1123004299972362241.text: We're sending the next man, and first woman, to the lunar South Pole by 2024. To do that, we're updating our call to American industry and broadening it to help us build and design an integrated human lunar lander system. Details: https://go.nasa.gov/2V93mq5  #Moon2024pic.twitter.com/tLIaRnFnHd

1118561763300184065.text: #Now 1970 - Jim Lovell (c), Jack Swigert (r) and Fred Haise (l) safely return to Earth after their "successful failure" on Apollo 13. Splashdown in the South Pacific came at 1:08 pm Eastern Time on April 17. Shown here on the recovery ship USS Iwo Jima.pic.twitter.com/S3vYW77Xei

1118326345845678080.text: While we get ready to send our @NASA_Astronauts farther than ever before, understanding the conditions of deep space is critical to keeping them safe & happy. A change they’ll encounter is a 50% increase in radiation. Here’s how we’re preparing for it: https://go.nasa.gov/2UHPB10 pic.twitter.com/2mmRX6DVca

1115665696833331200.text:
Heard about our plans to go to the Moon by 2024?  We’ve accelerated plans to get humans there as fast as possible, send humans & robots to explore more of the lunar surface, and make it sustainable to conduct long-term missions. Learn more: https://go.nasa.gov/2FYXAwC 
#Moon2024pic.twitter.com/TzcZJX2DoW

1118551491344850945.text:
With this all-star* cast, you’d think we’d be a shoe-in for this year’s #Webbys, but it’s up to the public to vote by April 18: http://wbby.co/vote-web53  See all the @NASA nominees at https://go.nasa.gov/2IcvyAm  
 
*Ok, one star, but lots of planets, asteroids and comets pic.twitter.com/1tFw42UxHm

1118195854828015624.text: NOW (12:54am ET) in 1972, Apollo 16 launches from @NASAKennedy. John Young, Ken Mattingly and Charlie Duke would arrive at the Moon about 4 days later to conduct an array of scientific experiments: https://go.nasa.gov/2UDNr2x  #Apollo50thpic.twitter.com/cKXqadWoMs

1117809637351358466.text: When micrometeoroids hit the lunar surface, they release water vapor that enters the Moon’s thin atmosphere. Some of this water falls back on the Moon and may be the source of water ice we’ve found at the Moon’s poles. https://go.nasa.gov/2UkSkIW pic.twitter.com/a2fPyYSSzs

1116108226121089024.text: Happy #NationalSiblingsDay to all my crazy moons out there. From ice-covered Europa to volcanic Io to little ravioli-shaped Pan, the moons of @NASASolarSystem represent a diverse range of what a world can be. https://go.nasa.gov/2GEFZfH pic.twitter.com/CZoGLAE4iu

1116352667188649989.text: Today, @TeamSpaceIL's Beresheet lander will be the first private company to attempt to land on the Moon. @NASA & @LRO_NASA contributed to the effort with guidance and an instrument onboard. Let's go Beresheet! (and here's what the Moon looks like today) https://go.nasa.gov/2Gh5UZV pic.twitter.com/2GzJIlJ9tV

1118948756060352512.text: The Moon will be opposite the Sun on April 19th at 11:12 UTC. The 4th full Moon of the year goes by Pink, Fish, Worm, Sap, or in Nez Perce tradition, 'Flower Time.' It's also the Paschal Moon and signals the upcoming celebrations of Passover and Easter. https://go.nasa.gov/2DjYLWM pic.twitter.com/AFrmUE8hLX

1116103770272935937.text:
This is just too exciting not to share. 

To give you a sense of scale: 

Our Sun is 26.7 million times the mass of the Moon. 
The black hole imaged by @ehtelescope has the mass of 6.5 billion Suns. https://twitter.com/NASA/status/1115992726800076800 …

1120411846698242049.text:
"We came all this way to explore the Moon, and the most important thing is that we discovered the Earth." - Bill Anders, Apollo 8 

Anders' iconic Earthrise photo taken in 1968 helped spark the first #EarthDay. Can you see why? #PictureEarthpic.twitter.com/r5PlnS8H1t

1118948757897449473.text: In the southern hemisphere, autumn is in full swing and this full Moon is the Hunter's Moon. https://svs.gsfc.nasa.gov/4442 . Happy lunar observing! #observethemoonpic.twitter.com/c8oA6Yshia

1118930543096344578.text: LADEE may have impacted the Moon #OTD 5 years ago, but its science lives on. Just this week, we announced that LADEE had found evidence of water vapor released from meteor impacts on the Moon! https://go.nasa.gov/2UkSkIW https://twitter.com/NASAhistory/status/1118876844349120514 …

1117809639196954624.text: The hydrated soil is drier than the driest desert  on Earth. You would need at least half a ton to yield one 8 oz. glass of water. https://go.nasa.gov/2UkSkIW

1118208022629822464.text: You may have heard that we plan to send humans to the Moon's South Pole by 2024. Why the South Pole? It's particularly interesting scientifically and contains useful resources - like water and extended sunlight. #Moon2024 https://go.nasa.gov/2IniWaL pic.twitter.com/qWuXH41R7T

1117809510981222400.text: Scientists on our LADEE mission have discovered a global layer of hydrated soil beneath the lunar surface. The water in the soil is ancient, possibly dating back to the formation of the Moon.  https://go.nasa.gov/2UkSkIW pic.twitter.com/VXgKBEOf7k

1121522799070281741.text: Blagg crater is named after Mary Adela Blagg (1858-1944). A Moon mapper extraordinaire, Blagg standardized the names of lunar features and became one of the first 5 women inducted as a fellow into the Royal Astronomical Society. Rock star. #WomenInSTEM http://lroc.sese.asu.edu/posts/1093 pic.twitter.com/i6Nb9JLNya
